title: 108_s1986
content: The "Protecting American Democracy Act of 2003" requires voter verification. The "Protecting American Democracy Act of 2003" mandates voter verification through a voting system that allows each voter to verify their vote and correct any errors before a permanent record is created. The verified vote produced under the system must be available as an official record and use accurate technology for voter verification before a permanent record is created. The voting system must ensure nondiscriminatory access for voters with disabilities, provide private voting options, and offer language accessibility as required by the Voting Rights Act of 1965. SEC. 3. REQUIRING INCREASED SECURITY FOR VOTING SYSTEMS. Increased security requirements for voting systems under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 include adherence to federal computer system security standards or stricter requirements set by the Election Assistance Commission. This entails prohibiting wireless devices in voting systems and certifying all software and hardware used in electronic voting systems through accredited laboratories. The Commission, with NIST, will report to Congress on a proposed security review process for voting systems within 6 months of the Protecting American Democracy Act of 2003. The Government Accounting Office will issue a report on operational systems within 3 months of the Act. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) will provide security consultation services to State and local jurisdictions with an authorized budget of $2,000,000 for each fiscal year starting in 2004. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) will provide security consultation services to State and local jurisdictions with an authorized budget of $2,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2006. The amendments made by this Act will be effective as if included in the enactment of the Help America Vote Act of 2002.
